column4: Mr. Cater
column5: of course it's a criticism that uh - is being made. Uh - I obviously don't think it's valid. I have supported the Administration's position and I think that that position has been correct; I think my position has been correct. As far as Indochina was concerned
column6: I stated over and over again that it was essential during that period that the United States make it clear that we would not tolerate Indochina falling under Communist domination. Now
column7: as a result of our taking the strong stand that we did
column8: the civil war there was ended; and today
column9: at least in the south of Indochina
column10: the Communists have moved out and we do have a strong
column11: free bastion there. Now
column12: looking to the U-2 flights
column13: I would like to point out that I have been supporting the President's position throughout. I think the President was correct in ordering these flights. I think the President was correct
column14: certainly
column15: in his decision to continue the flights while the conference was going on. I noted
column16: for example
column17: in reading a - uh - a - a particular discussion that Senator Kennedy had with Dave Garroway shortly after the uh - his statement about regrets
column18: that uh - he made the statement that he felt that these particular flights uh - were ones that shouldn't have occurred right at that time
column19: and the indication was how would Mr. Khrushchev had felt if we had uh - had a flight over the uni- how would we have felt if Mr. Khrushchev ha - uh - had a flight over the United States while uh - he was visiting here. And the answer
column21: is that Communist espionage goes on all the time. The answer is that the United States can't afford to have a es- an es - a espionage lack or should we s- uh - lag - or should I say uh - an intelligence lag - any more than we can afford to have a missile lag. Now
column22: referring to your question with regard to Quemoy and Matsu. What I object to here is the constant reference to surrendering these islands. Senator Kennedy quotes the record
column23: which he read from a moment ago
column24: but what he forgets to point out is that the key vote - a uh - vote which I've referred to several times - where he was in the minority was one which rejected his position. Now
column25: why did they reject it? For the very reason that those Senators knew
column26: as the President of the United States knew
column27: that you should not indicate to the Communists in advance that you're going to surrender an area that's free. Why? Because they know as Senator Kennedy will have to know that if you do that you encourage them to more aggression.

column1: Well number one on Indochina
column2: Mr. Nixon talked in - before the newspaper editors in the spring of 1954 about putting
column4: ""American boys into Indochina."" The reason Indochina was preserved was the result of the Geneva Conference which Indochina. Number two
column5: on the question of the U-2 flights. I thought the. U-2 flight in May just before the conference was a mistake in timing because of the hazards involved
column6: if the summit conference had any hope for success. I never criticized the U-2 flights in general
column7: however. I never suggested espionage should stop. It still goes on
column8: I would assume
column9: on both sides. Number three
column10: the Vice President - on May fifteenth after the U-2 flight - indicated that the flights were going on
column11: even though the Administration and the President had canceled the flights on May twelfth. Number three
column12: the pre - Vice President suggests that we should keep the Communists in doubt about whether we would fight on Quemoy and Matsu. That's not the position he's taking. He's indicating that we should fight for these islands come what may because they are
column13: in his words
column14: in the area of freedom. He didn't take that position on Tibet. He didn't take that position on Budapest. He doesn't take that position that I've seen so far in Laos. Guinea and Ghana have both moved within the Soviet sphere of influence in foreign policy; so has Cuba. I merely say that the United States should meet its commitments to Que- to uh - Formosa and the Pescadores. But as Admiral Yarnell has said
column15: and he's been supported by most military authority
column16: these islands that we're now talking about are not worth the bones of a single American soldier; and I know how difficult it is to sustain troops close to the shore under artillery bombardment. And therefore
column18: we should make it very clear the disagreement between Mr. Nixon and myself. He's extending the Administration's commitment.

column21: is that Communist espionage goes on all the time. The answer is that the United States can't afford to have a es- an es - a espionage lack or should we s- uh - lag - or should I say uh - an intelligence lag - any more than we can afford to have a missile lag. Now

column1: Well number one on Indochina
column2: Mr. Nixon talked in - before the newspaper editors in the spring of 1954 about putting
column4: ""American boys into Indochina."" The reason Indochina was preserved was the result of the Geneva Conference which Indochina. Number two
column5: on the question of the U-2 flights. I thought the. U-2 flight in May just before the conference was a mistake in timing because of the hazards involved
column6: if the summit conference had any hope for success. I never criticized the U-2 flights in general
column7: however. I never suggested espionage should stop. It still goes on
column8: I would assume
column9: on both sides. Number three
column10: the Vice President - on May fifteenth after the U-2 flight - indicated that the flights were going on
column11: even though the Administration and the President had canceled the flights on May twelfth. Number three
column12: the pre - Vice President suggests that we should keep the Communists in doubt about whether we would fight on Quemoy and Matsu. That's not the position he's taking. He's indicating that we should fight for these islands come what may because they are
column13: in his words
column14: in the area of freedom. He didn't take that position on Tibet. He didn't take that position on Budapest. He doesn't take that position that I've seen so far in Laos. Guinea and Ghana have both moved within the Soviet sphere of influence in foreign policy; so has Cuba. I merely say that the United States should meet its commitments to Que- to uh - Formosa and the Pescadores. But as Admiral Yarnell has said
column15: and he's been supported by most military authority
column16: these islands that we're now talking about are not worth the bones of a single American soldier; and I know how difficult it is to sustain troops close to the shore under artillery bombardment. And therefore
column18: we should make it very clear the disagreement between Mr. Nixon and myself. He's extending the Administration's commitment.

column4: ""American boys into Indochina."" The reason Indochina was preserved was the result of the Geneva Conference which Indochina. Number two

column14: in the area of freedom. He didn't take that position on Tibet. He didn't take that position on Budapest. He doesn't take that position that I've seen so far in Laos. Guinea and Ghana have both moved within the Soviet sphere of influence in foreign policy; so has Cuba. I merely say that the United States should meet its commitments to Que- to uh - Formosa and the Pescadores. But as Admiral Yarnell has said

column1: Well number one on Indochina
column2: Mr. Nixon talked in - before the newspaper editors in the spring of 1954 about putting
column4: ""American boys into Indochina."" The reason Indochina was preserved was the result of the Geneva Conference which Indochina. Number two
column5: on the question of the U-2 flights. I thought the. U-2 flight in May just before the conference was a mistake in timing because of the hazards involved
column6: if the summit conference had any hope for success. I never criticized the U-2 flights in general
column7: however. I never suggested espionage should stop. It still goes on
column8: I would assume
column9: on both sides. Number three
column10: the Vice President - on May fifteenth after the U-2 flight - indicated that the flights were going on
column11: even though the Administration and the President had canceled the flights on May twelfth. Number three
column12: the pre - Vice President suggests that we should keep the Communists in doubt about whether we would fight on Quemoy and Matsu. That's not the position he's taking. He's indicating that we should fight for these islands come what may because they are
column13: in his words
column14: in the area of freedom. He didn't take that position on Tibet. He didn't take that position on Budapest. He doesn't take that position that I've seen so far in Laos. Guinea and Ghana have both moved within the Soviet sphere of influence in foreign policy; so has Cuba. I merely say that the United States should meet its commitments to Que- to uh - Formosa and the Pescadores. But as Admiral Yarnell has said
column15: and he's been supported by most military authority
column16: these islands that we're now talking about are not worth the bones of a single American soldier; and I know how difficult it is to sustain troops close to the shore under artillery bombardment. And therefore
column18: we should make it very clear the disagreement between Mr. Nixon and myself. He's extending the Administration's commitment.

column1: Well number one on Indochina
column2: Mr. Nixon talked in - before the newspaper editors in the spring of 1954 about putting
column4: ""American boys into Indochina."" The reason Indochina was preserved was the result of the Geneva Conference which Indochina. Number two
column5: on the question of the U-2 flights. I thought the. U-2 flight in May just before the conference was a mistake in timing because of the hazards involved
column6: if the summit conference had any hope for success. I never criticized the U-2 flights in general
column7: however. I never suggested espionage should stop. It still goes on
column8: I would assume

column13: in his words
column14: in the area of freedom. He didn't take that position on Tibet. He didn't take that position on Budapest. He doesn't take that position that I've seen so far in Laos. Guinea and Ghana have both moved within the Soviet sphere of influence in foreign policy; so has Cuba. I merely say that the United States should meet its commitments to Que- to uh - Formosa and the Pescadores. But as Admiral Yarnell has said
column15: and he's been supported by most military authority
column16: these islands that we're now talking about are not worth the bones of a single American soldier; and I know how difficult it is to sustain troops close to the shore under artillery bombardment. And therefore
column18: we should make it very clear the disagreement between Mr. Nixon and myself. He's extending the Administration's commitment.

column1: Well I welcome this opportunity to join Senator Kennedy completely on that statement and to say before this largest television audience in history something that I have been saying in the past and want to - will always say in the future. On our last television debate
column2: I pointed out that it was my position that Americans must choose the best man that either party could produce. We can't settle for anything but the best. And that means
column4: the best man that this nation can produce. And that means that we can't have any test of religion. We can't have any test of race. It must be a test of a man. Also as far as religion is concerned. I have seen Communism abroad. I see what it does. Communism is the enemy of all religions; and we who do believe in God must join together. We must not be divided on this issue. The worst thing that I can think can happen in this campaign would be for it to be decided on religious issues. I obviously repudiate the Klan; I repudiate anybody who uses the religious issue; I will not tolerate it
column5: I have ordered all of my people to have nothing to do with it and I say - say to this great audience
column6: whoever may be listening
column7: remember
column8: if you believe in America
column9: if you want America to set the right example to the world
column10: that we cannot have religious or racial prejudice. We cannot have it in our hearts. But we certainly cannot have it in a presidential campaign.

column1: Well I welcome this opportunity to join Senator Kennedy completely on that statement and to say before this largest television audience in history something that I have been saying in the past and want to - will always say in the future. On our last television debate
column2: I pointed out that it was my position that Americans must choose the best man that either party could produce. We can't settle for anything but the best. And that means
column4: the best man that this nation can produce. And that means that we can't have any test of religion. We can't have any test of race. It must be a test of a man. Also as far as religion is concerned. I have seen Communism abroad. I see what it does. Communism is the enemy of all religions; and we who do believe in God must join together. We must not be divided on this issue. The worst thing that I can think can happen in this campaign would be for it to be decided on religious issues. I obviously repudiate the Klan; I repudiate anybody who uses the religious issue; I will not tolerate it
column5: I have ordered all of my people to have nothing to do with it and I say - say to this great audience
column6: whoever may be listening
column7: remember
column8: if you believe in America
column9: if you want America to set the right example to the world
column10: that we cannot have religious or racial prejudice. We cannot have it in our hearts. But we certainly cannot have it in a presidential campaign.

column1: Well I welcome this opportunity to join Senator Kennedy completely on that statement and to say before this largest television audience in history something that I have been saying in the past and want to - will always say in the future. On our last television debate
column2: I pointed out that it was my position that Americans must choose the best man that either party could produce. We can't settle for anything but the best. And that means
column4: the best man that this nation can produce. And that means that we can't have any test of religion. We can't have any test of race. It must be a test of a man. Also as far as religion is concerned. I have seen Communism abroad. I see what it does. Communism is the enemy of all religions; and we who do believe in God must join together. We must not be divided on this issue. The worst thing that I can think can happen in this campaign would be for it to be decided on religious issues. I obviously repudiate the Klan; I repudiate anybody who uses the religious issue; I will not tolerate it
column5: I have ordered all of my people to have nothing to do with it and I say - say to this great audience
column6: whoever may be listening
column7: remember
column8: if you believe in America
column9: if you want America to set the right example to the world
column10: that we cannot have religious or racial prejudice. We cannot have it in our hearts. But we certainly cannot have it in a presidential campaign.

column1: Well I welcome this opportunity to join Senator Kennedy completely on that statement and to say before this largest television audience in history something that I have been saying in the past and want to - will always say in the future. On our last television debate
column2: I pointed out that it was my position that Americans must choose the best man that either party could produce. We can't settle for anything but the best. And that means
column4: the best man that this nation can produce. And that means that we can't have any test of religion. We can't have any test of race. It must be a test of a man. Also as far as religion is concerned. I have seen Communism abroad. I see what it does. Communism is the enemy of all religions; and we who do believe in God must join together. We must not be divided on this issue. The worst thing that I can think can happen in this campaign would be for it to be decided on religious issues. I obviously repudiate the Klan; I repudiate anybody who uses the religious issue; I will not tolerate it
column5: I have ordered all of my people to have nothing to do with it and I say - say to this great audience
column6: whoever may be listening
column7: remember
column8: if you believe in America
column9: if you want America to set the right example to the world
column10: that we cannot have religious or racial prejudice. We cannot have it in our hearts. But we certainly cannot have it in a presidential campaign.

column4: I am planning a speech on that subject next week. Uh - Also
column5: so that we can get the uh - opportunity for the questioners to question me
column6: it will be before the next television debate. Uh - I will say simply
column7: in advance of it
column8: that I believe that in this area
column9: the laws which should be passed uh - as far as the big national emergency strikes are concerned
column10: are ones that will give the president more weapons with which to deal with those strikes. Now
column11: I have a basic disagreement with Senator Kennedy
column12: though
column13: on this point. He has taken the position
column14: when he first indicated in October of last year
column15: that he would even favor compulsory arbitration as one of the weapons the president might have to stop a national emergency strike. I understand in his last speech before the Steelworkers Union
column16: that he changed that position and indicated that he felt that government seizure might be the best way to stop a strike which could not be settled by collective bargaining. I do not believe we should have either compulsory arbitration or seizure. I think the moment that you give to the union
column18: and to management
column19: on the other side
column20: the escape hatch of eventually going to government to get it settled
column21: that most of these great strikes will end up being settled by government
column22: and that will be a - be in the end
column24: wage control; it would mean price control - all the things that we do not want. I do believe
column25: however
column26: that we can give to the president of the United States powers
column27: in addition to what he presently has in the fact finding area
column28: which would enable him to be more effective than we have been in handling these strikes. One last point I should make. The record in handling them has been very good during this Administration. We have had less man-hours lost by strikes in these last seven years than we had in the previous seven years
column29: by a great deal. And I only want to say that however good the record is
column30: it's got to be better. Because in this critical year - period of the sixties we've got to move forward
column31: all Americans must move forward together
column32: and we have to get the greatest cooperation possible between labor and management. We cannot afford stoppages of massive effect on the economy when we're in the terrible competition we're in with the Soviets.

column1: Well
column2: I always have difficulty recognizing my positions when they're stated by the Vice President. I never suggested that compulsory arbitration was the solution for national emergency disputes. I'm opposed to that
column3: was opposed to it in October
column4: 1958. I have suggested that the president should be given other weapons to protect the national interest in case of national emergency strikes beyond the injunction provision of the Taft-Hartley Act. I don't know what other weapons the Vice President is talking about. I'm talking about giving him four or five tools - not only the fact-finding committee that he now has under the injunction provision
column5: not only the injunction
column6: but also the power of the fact-finding commission to make recommendations - recommendations which would not be binding
column7: but nevertheless would have great force of public opinion behind them. One of the additional powers that I would suggest would be seizure. There might be others. By the president having five powers - four or five powers - and he only has very limited powers today
column8: neither the company nor the union would be sure which power would be used; and therefore
column9: there would be a greater incentive on both sides to reach an agreement themselves without taking it to the government. The difficulty now is the president's course is quite limited. He can set up a fact-finding committee. The fact-finding committee's powers are limited. He can provide an injunction if there's a national emergency for eighty days
column10: then the strike can go on; and there are no other powers or actions that the president could take unless he went to the Congress. This is a difficult and sensitive matter. But to state my view precisely
column11: the president should have a variety of things he could do. He could leave the parties in doubt as to which one he would use; and therefore there would be incentive
column12: instead of as now - the steel companies were ready to take the strike because they felt the injunction of eighty days would break the union
column13: which didn't happen.

column1: Because in this critical year - period of the sixties we've got to move forward, all Americans must move forward together, and we have to get the greatest cooperation possible between labor and management. column1: Well
column2: I always have difficulty recognizing my positions when they're stated by the Vice President. I never suggested that compulsory arbitration was the solution for national emergency disputes. I'm opposed to that
column3: was opposed to it in October
column4: 1958. I have suggested that the president should be given other weapons to protect the national interest in case of national emergency strikes beyond the injunction provision of the Taft-Hartley Act. I don't know what other weapons the Vice President is talking about. I'm talking about giving him four or five tools - not only the fact-finding committee that he now has under the injunction provision
column5: not only the injunction
column6: but also the power of the fact-finding commission to make recommendations - recommendations which would not be binding
column7: but nevertheless would have great force of public opinion behind them. One of the additional powers that I would suggest would be seizure. There might be others. By the president having five powers - four or five powers - and he only has very limited powers today
column8: neither the company nor the union would be sure which power would be used; and therefore
column9: there would be a greater incentive on both sides to reach an agreement themselves without taking it to the government. The difficulty now is the president's course is quite limited. He can set up a fact-finding committee. The fact-finding committee's powers are limited. He can provide an injunction if there's a national emergency for eighty days
column10: then the strike can go on; and there are no other powers or actions that the president could take unless he went to the Congress. This is a difficult and sensitive matter. But to state my view precisely
column11: the president should have a variety of things he could do. He could leave the parties in doubt as to which one he would use; and therefore there would be incentive
column12: instead of as now - the steel companies were ready to take the strike because they felt the injunction of eighty days would break the union
column13: which didn't happen.

column4: I am planning a speech on that subject next week. Uh - Also
column5: so that we can get the uh - opportunity for the questioners to question me
column6: it will be before the next television debate. Uh - I will say simply
column7: in advance of it
column8: that I believe that in this area
column9: the laws which should be passed uh - as far as the big national emergency strikes are concerned
column10: are ones that will give the president more weapons with which to deal with those strikes. Now
column11: I have a basic disagreement with Senator Kennedy
column12: though
column13: on this point. He has taken the position
column14: when he first indicated in October of last year
column15: that he would even favor compulsory arbitration as one of the weapons the president might have to stop a national emergency strike. I understand in his last speech before the Steelworkers Union
column16: that he changed that position and indicated that he felt that government seizure might be the best way to stop a strike which could not be settled by collective bargaining. I do not believe we should have either compulsory arbitration or seizure. I think the moment that you give to the union
column18: and to management
column19: on the other side
column20: the escape hatch of eventually going to government to get it settled
column21: that most of these great strikes will end up being settled by government
column22: and that will be a - be in the end
column24: wage control; it would mean price control - all the things that we do not want. I do believe
column25: however
column26: that we can give to the president of the United States powers
column27: in addition to what he presently has in the fact finding area
column28: which would enable him to be more effective than we have been in handling these strikes. One last point I should make. The record in handling them has been very good during this Administration. We have had less man-hours lost by strikes in these last seven years than we had in the previous seven years
column29: by a great deal. And I only want to say that however good the record is
column30: it's got to be better. Because in this critical year - period of the sixties we've got to move forward
column31: all Americans must move forward together
column32: and we have to get the greatest cooperation possible between labor and management. We cannot afford stoppages of massive effect on the economy when we're in the terrible competition we're in with the Soviets.

column1: Well
column2: I always have difficulty recognizing my positions when they're stated by the Vice President. I never suggested that compulsory arbitration was the solution for national emergency disputes. I'm opposed to that
column3: was opposed to it in October
column4: 1958. I have suggested that the president should be given other weapons to protect the national interest in case of national emergency strikes beyond the injunction provision of the Taft-Hartley Act. I don't know what other weapons the Vice President is talking about. I'm talking about giving him four or five tools - not only the fact-finding committee that he now has under the injunction provision
column5: not only the injunction
column6: but also the power of the fact-finding commission to make recommendations - recommendations which would not be binding
column7: but nevertheless would have great force of public opinion behind them. One of the additional powers that I would suggest would be seizure. There might be others. By the president having five powers - four or five powers - and he only has very limited powers today
column8: neither the company nor the union would be sure which power would be used; and therefore
column9: there would be a greater incentive on both sides to reach an agreement themselves without taking it to the government. The difficulty now is the president's course is quite limited. He can set up a fact-finding committee. The fact-finding committee's powers are limited. He can provide an injunction if there's a national emergency for eighty days
column10: then the strike can go on; and there are no other powers or actions that the president could take unless he went to the Congress. This is a difficult and sensitive matter. But to state my view precisely
column11: the president should have a variety of things he could do. He could leave the parties in doubt as to which one he would use; and therefore there would be incentive
column12: instead of as now - the steel companies were ready to take the strike because they felt the injunction of eighty days would break the union
column13: which didn't happen.

column24: wage control; it would mean price control - all the things that we do not want. I do believe
column25: however
column26: that we can give to the president of the United States powers
column27: in addition to what he presently has in the fact finding area
column28: which would enable him to be more effective than we have been in handling these strikes. One last point I should make. The record in handling them has been very good during this Administration. We have had less man-hours lost by strikes in these last seven years than we had in the previous seven years
column29: by a great deal. And I only want to say that however good the record is
column30: it's got to be better. Because in this critical year - period of the sixties we've got to move forward
column31: all Americans must move forward together
column32: and we have to get the greatest cooperation possible between labor and management. We cannot afford stoppages of massive effect on the economy when we're in the terrible competition we're in with the Soviets.

column1: Well
column2: I always have difficulty recognizing my positions when they're stated by the Vice President. I never suggested that compulsory arbitration was the solution for national emergency disputes. I'm opposed to that
column3: was opposed to it in October
column4: 1958. I have suggested that the president should be given other weapons to protect the national interest in case of national emergency strikes beyond the injunction provision of the Taft-Hartley Act. I don't know what other weapons the Vice President is talking about. I'm talking about giving him four or five tools - not only the fact-finding committee that he now has under the injunction provision
column5: not only the injunction
column6: but also the power of the fact-finding commission to make recommendations - recommendations which would not be binding
column7: but nevertheless would have great force of public opinion behind them. One of the additional powers that I would suggest would be seizure. There might be others. By the president having five powers - four or five powers - and he only has very limited powers today
column8: neither the company nor the union would be sure which power would be used; and therefore
column9: there would be a greater incentive on both sides to reach an agreement themselves without taking it to the government. The difficulty now is the president's course is quite limited. He can set up a fact-finding committee. The fact-finding committee's powers are limited. He can provide an injunction if there's a national emergency for eighty days
column10: then the strike can go on; and there are no other powers or actions that the president could take unless he went to the Congress. This is a difficult and sensitive matter. But to state my view precisely
column11: the president should have a variety of things he could do. He could leave the parties in doubt as to which one he would use; and therefore there would be incentive
column12: instead of as now - the steel companies were ready to take the strike because they felt the injunction of eighty days would break the union
column13: which didn't happen.

column4: I have stated in both uh - debates and state again that I believe in a balanced budget and have supported that concept during my fourteen years in the Congress. The only two times when an unbalanced budget is warranted would be during a serious recession - and we had that in fifty-eight in an unbalanced budget of twelve billion dollars - or a national emergency where there should be large expenditures for national defense
column5: which we had in World War II and uh - during part of the Korean War. On the question of the cost of our budget
column6: I have stated that it's my best judgment that our agricultural program will cost a billion and a half
column7: possibly two billion dollars less than the present agricultural program. My judgment is that the program the Vice President put forward
column8: which is an extension of Mr. Benson's program
column9: will cost a billion dollars more than the present program
column10: which costs about six billion dollars a year
column11: the most expensive in history. We've spent more money on agriculture in the last eight years than the hundred years of the Agricultural Department before that. Secondly
column12: I believe that the high interest-rate policy that this Administration has followed has added about three billion dollars a year to interest on the debt - merely funding the debt - which is a burden an the taxpayers. I would hope
column13: under a different monetary policy
column14: that it would be possible to reduce that interest-rate burden
column15: at least a billion dollars. Third
column16: I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding
column18: I have suggested that the medical care for the aged - and the bill which the Congress now has passed and the President signed if fully implemented would cost a billion dollars on the Treasury - out of Treasury funds and a billion dollars by the states - the proposal that I have put forward and which many of the members of my party support is for medical care financed under Social Security; which would be financed under the Social Security taxes; which is less than three cents a day per person for medical care
column19: doctors' bills
column22: when they retire. It is actuarially sound. So in my judgment we would spend more money in this Administration on aid to education
column23: we'd spend more money on housing
column24: we'd spend more money and I hope more wisely on defense than this Administration has. But I believe that the next Administration should work for a balanced budget
column25: and that would be my intention. Mr. Nixon misstates my figures constantly
column26: which uh - is of course his right
column27: but the fact of the matter is: here is where I stand and I just want to have it on the public record.

column1: Senator Kennedy has indicated on several occasions in this program tonight that I have been misstating his record and his figures. I will issue a white paper after this broadcast
column2: quoting exactly what he said on compulsory arbitration
column4: and the record will show that I have been correct. Now as far as his figures are concerned here tonight
column5: he again is engaging in this
column6: what I would call
column7: mirror game of ""here-it-is-and-here-it-isn't."" Uh - On the one hand
column8: for example
column9: he suggests that as far as his medical care program is concerned that that really isn't a problem because it's from Social Security. But Social Security is a tax. The people pay it. It comes right out of your paycheck. This doesn't mean that the people aren't going to be paying the bill. He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours. Well
column10: all that I can suggest is that all the experts who have studied the program indicate that it is the most fantastic program
column11: the worst program
column12: insofar as its effect on the farmers
column13: that the - America has ever had foisted upon it in an election year or any other time. And I would also point out that Senator Kennedy left out a part of the cost of that program - a twenty-five percent rise in food prices that the people would have to pay. Now are we going to have that when it isn't going to help the farmers? I don't think we should have that kind of a program. Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way. Well
column14: what he is saying there in effect
column15: we're going to have inflation. We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board. I don't believe we ought to pay our bills through inflation
column16: through a phony interest rate.

column4: I have stated in both uh - debates and state again that I believe in a balanced budget and have supported that concept during my fourteen years in the Congress. column11: the most expensive in history. We've spent more money on agriculture in the last eight years than the hundred years of the Agricultural Department before that. Secondly

column15: at least a billion dollars. Third
column16: I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding

column19: doctors' bills

column4: I have stated in both uh - debates and state again that I believe in a balanced budget and have supported that concept during my fourteen years in the Congress. The only two times when an unbalanced budget is warranted would be during a serious recession - and we had that in fifty-eight in an unbalanced budget of twelve billion dollars - or a national emergency where there should be large expenditures for national defense
column5: which we had in World War II and uh - during part of the Korean War. On the question of the cost of our budget
column6: I have stated that it's my best judgment that our agricultural program will cost a billion and a half
column7: possibly two billion dollars less than the present agricultural program. My judgment is that the program the Vice President put forward
column8: which is an extension of Mr. Benson's program
column9: will cost a billion dollars more than the present program
column10: which costs about six billion dollars a year
column11: the most expensive in history. We've spent more money on agriculture in the last eight years than the hundred years of the Agricultural Department before that. Secondly
column12: I believe that the high interest-rate policy that this Administration has followed has added about three billion dollars a year to interest on the debt - merely funding the debt - which is a burden an the taxpayers. I would hope
column13: under a different monetary policy
column14: that it would be possible to reduce that interest-rate burden
column15: at least a billion dollars. Third
column16: I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding
column18: I have suggested that the medical care for the aged - and the bill which the Congress now has passed and the President signed if fully implemented would cost a billion dollars on the Treasury - out of Treasury funds and a billion dollars by the states - the proposal that I have put forward and which many of the members of my party support is for medical care financed under Social Security; which would be financed under the Social Security taxes; which is less than three cents a day per person for medical care
column19: doctors' bills
column22: when they retire. It is actuarially sound. So in my judgment we would spend more money in this Administration on aid to education
column23: we'd spend more money on housing
column24: we'd spend more money and I hope more wisely on defense than this Administration has. But I believe that the next Administration should work for a balanced budget
column25: and that would be my intention. Mr. Nixon misstates my figures constantly
column26: which uh - is of course his right
column27: but the fact of the matter is: here is where I stand and I just want to have it on the public record.

column1: Senator Kennedy has indicated on several occasions in this program tonight that I have been misstating his record and his figures. I will issue a white paper after this broadcast
column2: quoting exactly what he said on compulsory arbitration
column4: and the record will show that I have been correct. Now as far as his figures are concerned here tonight
column5: he again is engaging in this
column6: what I would call
column7: mirror game of ""here-it-is-and-here-it-isn't."" Uh - On the one hand
column8: for example
column9: he suggests that as far as his medical care program is concerned that that really isn't a problem because it's from Social Security. But Social Security is a tax. The people pay it. It comes right out of your paycheck. This doesn't mean that the people aren't going to be paying the bill. He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours. Well
column10: all that I can suggest is that all the experts who have studied the program indicate that it is the most fantastic program
column11: the worst program
column12: insofar as its effect on the farmers
column13: that the - America has ever had foisted upon it in an election year or any other time. And I would also point out that Senator Kennedy left out a part of the cost of that program - a twenty-five percent rise in food prices that the people would have to pay. Now are we going to have that when it isn't going to help the farmers? I don't think we should have that kind of a program. Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way. Well
column14: what he is saying there in effect
column15: we're going to have inflation. We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board. I don't believe we ought to pay our bills through inflation
column16: through a phony interest rate.

column4: I have stated in both uh - debates and state again that I believe in a balanced budget and have supported that concept during my fourteen years in the Congress. The only two times when an unbalanced budget is warranted would be during a serious recession - and we had that in fifty-eight in an unbalanced budget of twelve billion dollars - or a national emergency where there should be large expenditures for national defense
column5: which we had in World War II and uh - during part of the Korean War. On the question of the cost of our budget
column6: I have stated that it's my best judgment that our agricultural program will cost a billion and a half
column7: possibly two billion dollars less than the present agricultural program. My judgment is that the program the Vice President put forward
column8: which is an extension of Mr. Benson's program
column9: will cost a billion dollars more than the present program
column10: which costs about six billion dollars a year
column11: the most expensive in history. We've spent more money on agriculture in the last eight years than the hundred years of the Agricultural Department before that. Secondly
column12: I believe that the high interest-rate policy that this Administration has followed has added about three billion dollars a year to interest on the debt - merely funding the debt - which is a burden an the taxpayers. I would hope
column13: under a different monetary policy
column14: that it would be possible to reduce that interest-rate burden
column15: at least a billion dollars. Third
column16: I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding
column18: I have suggested that the medical care for the aged - and the bill which the Congress now has passed and the President signed if fully implemented would cost a billion dollars on the Treasury - out of Treasury funds and a billion dollars by the states - the proposal that I have put forward and which many of the members of my party support is for medical care financed under Social Security; which would be financed under the Social Security taxes; which is less than three cents a day per person for medical care
column19: doctors' bills
column22: when they retire. It is actuarially sound. So in my judgment we would spend more money in this Administration on aid to education
column23: we'd spend more money on housing
column24: we'd spend more money and I hope more wisely on defense than this Administration has. But I believe that the next Administration should work for a balanced budget
column25: and that would be my intention. Mr. Nixon misstates my figures constantly
column26: which uh - is of course his right
column27: but the fact of the matter is: here is where I stand and I just want to have it on the public record.

column1: Senator Kennedy has indicated on several occasions in this program tonight that I have been misstating his record and his figures. I will issue a white paper after this broadcast
column2: quoting exactly what he said on compulsory arbitration
column4: and the record will show that I have been correct. Now as far as his figures are concerned here tonight
column5: he again is engaging in this
column6: what I would call
column7: mirror game of ""here-it-is-and-here-it-isn't."" Uh - On the one hand
column8: for example
column9: he suggests that as far as his medical care program is concerned that that really isn't a problem because it's from Social Security. But Social Security is a tax. The people pay it. It comes right out of your paycheck. This doesn't mean that the people aren't going to be paying the bill. He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours. Well
column10: all that I can suggest is that all the experts who have studied the program indicate that it is the most fantastic program
column11: the worst program
column12: insofar as its effect on the farmers
column13: that the - America has ever had foisted upon it in an election year or any other time. And I would also point out that Senator Kennedy left out a part of the cost of that program - a twenty-five percent rise in food prices that the people would have to pay. Now are we going to have that when it isn't going to help the farmers? I don't think we should have that kind of a program. Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way. Well
column14: what he is saying there in effect
column15: we're going to have inflation. We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board. I don't believe we ought to pay our bills through inflation
column16: through a phony interest rate.

column4: I have stated in both uh - debates and state again that I believe in a balanced budget and have supported that concept during my fourteen years in the Congress. column10: which costs about six billion dollars a year
column11: the most expensive in history. We've spent more money on agriculture in the last eight years than the hundred years of the Agricultural Department before that. Secondly

column13: under a different monetary policy
column14: that it would be possible to reduce that interest-rate burden
column15: at least a billion dollars. Third
column16: I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding
column18: I have suggested that the medical care for the aged - and the bill which the Congress now has passed and the President signed if fully implemented would cost a billion dollars on the Treasury - out of Treasury funds and a billion dollars by the states - the proposal that I have put forward and which many of the members of my party support is for medical care financed under Social Security; which would be financed under the Social Security taxes; which is less than three cents a day per person for medical care
column19: doctors' bills

column1: Senator Kennedy has indicated on several occasions in this program tonight that I have been misstating his record and his figures. I will issue a white paper after this broadcast
column2: quoting exactly what he said on compulsory arbitration
column4: and the record will show that I have been correct. Now as far as his figures are concerned here tonight
column5: he again is engaging in this

column7: mirror game of ""here-it-is-and-here-it-isn't."" Uh - On the one hand
column8: for example
column9: he suggests that as far as his medical care program is concerned that that really isn't a problem because it's from Social Security. But Social Security is a tax. The people pay it. It comes right out of your paycheck. This doesn't mean that the people aren't going to be paying the bill. He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours. Well
column10: all that I can suggest is that all the experts who have studied the program indicate that it is the most fantastic program
column11: the worst program
column12: insofar as its effect on the farmers
column13: that the - America has ever had foisted upon it in an election year or any other time. And I would also point out that Senator Kennedy left out a part of the cost of that program - a twenty-five percent rise in food prices that the people would have to pay. Now are we going to have that when it isn't going to help the farmers? I don't think we should have that kind of a program. Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way. Well
column14: what he is saying there in effect
column15: we're going to have inflation. We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board. I don't believe we ought to pay our bills through inflation
column16: through a phony interest rate.

column4: I have stated in both uh - debates and state again that I believe in a balanced budget and have supported that concept during my fourteen years in the Congress. The only two times when an unbalanced budget is warranted would be during a serious recession - and we had that in fifty-eight in an unbalanced budget of twelve billion dollars - or a national emergency where there should be large expenditures for national defense
column5: which we had in World War II and uh - during part of the Korean War. On the question of the cost of our budget
column6: I have stated that it's my best judgment that our agricultural program will cost a billion and a half
column7: possibly two billion dollars less than the present agricultural program. My judgment is that the program the Vice President put forward
column8: which is an extension of Mr. Benson's program
column9: will cost a billion dollars more than the present program
column10: which costs about six billion dollars a year
column11: the most expensive in history. We've spent more money on agriculture in the last eight years than the hundred years of the Agricultural Department before that. Secondly
column12: I believe that the high interest-rate policy that this Administration has followed has added about three billion dollars a year to interest on the debt - merely funding the debt - which is a burden an the taxpayers. I would hope
column13: under a different monetary policy
column14: that it would be possible to reduce that interest-rate burden
column15: at least a billion dollars. Third
column16: I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding
column18: I have suggested that the medical care for the aged - and the bill which the Congress now has passed and the President signed if fully implemented would cost a billion dollars on the Treasury - out of Treasury funds and a billion dollars by the states - the proposal that I have put forward and which many of the members of my party support is for medical care financed under Social Security; which would be financed under the Social Security taxes; which is less than three cents a day per person for medical care
column19: doctors' bills
column22: when they retire. It is actuarially sound. So in my judgment we would spend more money in this Administration on aid to education
column23: we'd spend more money on housing
column24: we'd spend more money and I hope more wisely on defense than this Administration has. But I believe that the next Administration should work for a balanced budget
column25: and that would be my intention. Mr. Nixon misstates my figures constantly
column26: which uh - is of course his right
column27: but the fact of the matter is: here is where I stand and I just want to have it on the public record.

column1: Senator Kennedy has indicated on several occasions in this program tonight that I have been misstating his record and his figures. I will issue a white paper after this broadcast
column2: quoting exactly what he said on compulsory arbitration
column4: and the record will show that I have been correct. Now as far as his figures are concerned here tonight
column5: he again is engaging in this
column6: what I would call
column7: mirror game of ""here-it-is-and-here-it-isn't."" Uh - On the one hand
column8: for example
column9: he suggests that as far as his medical care program is concerned that that really isn't a problem because it's from Social Security. But Social Security is a tax. The people pay it. It comes right out of your paycheck. This doesn't mean that the people aren't going to be paying the bill. He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours. Well
column10: all that I can suggest is that all the experts who have studied the program indicate that it is the most fantastic program
column11: the worst program
column12: insofar as its effect on the farmers
column13: that the - America has ever had foisted upon it in an election year or any other time. And I would also point out that Senator Kennedy left out a part of the cost of that program - a twenty-five percent rise in food prices that the people would have to pay. Now are we going to have that when it isn't going to help the farmers? I don't think we should have that kind of a program. Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way. Well
column14: what he is saying there in effect
column15: we're going to have inflation. We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board. I don't believe we ought to pay our bills through inflation
column16: through a phony interest rate.

column4: I have stated in both uh - debates and state again that I believe in a balanced budget and have supported that concept during my fourteen years in the Congress. The only two times when an unbalanced budget is warranted would be during a serious recession - and we had that in fifty-eight in an unbalanced budget of twelve billion dollars - or a national emergency where there should be large expenditures for national defense
column5: which we had in World War II and uh - during part of the Korean War. On the question of the cost of our budget
column6: I have stated that it's my best judgment that our agricultural program will cost a billion and a half
column7: possibly two billion dollars less than the present agricultural program. My judgment is that the program the Vice President put forward
column8: which is an extension of Mr. Benson's program
column9: will cost a billion dollars more than the present program
column10: which costs about six billion dollars a year
column11: the most expensive in history. We've spent more money on agriculture in the last eight years than the hundred years of the Agricultural Department before that. Secondly
column12: I believe that the high interest-rate policy that this Administration has followed has added about three billion dollars a year to interest on the debt - merely funding the debt - which is a burden an the taxpayers. I would hope
column13: under a different monetary policy
column14: that it would be possible to reduce that interest-rate burden
column15: at least a billion dollars. Third
column16: I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding
column18: I have suggested that the medical care for the aged - and the bill which the Congress now has passed and the President signed if fully implemented would cost a billion dollars on the Treasury - out of Treasury funds and a billion dollars by the states - the proposal that I have put forward and which many of the members of my party support is for medical care financed under Social Security; which would be financed under the Social Security taxes; which is less than three cents a day per person for medical care
column19: doctors' bills
column22: when they retire. It is actuarially sound. So in my judgment we would spend more money in this Administration on aid to education
column23: we'd spend more money on housing
column24: we'd spend more money and I hope more wisely on defense than this Administration has. But I believe that the next Administration should work for a balanced budget
column25: and that would be my intention. Mr. Nixon misstates my figures constantly
column26: which uh - is of course his right
column27: but the fact of the matter is: here is where I stand and I just want to have it on the public record.

column1: Senator Kennedy has indicated on several occasions in this program tonight that I have been misstating his record and his figures. I will issue a white paper after this broadcast
column2: quoting exactly what he said on compulsory arbitration
column4: and the record will show that I have been correct. Now as far as his figures are concerned here tonight
column5: he again is engaging in this
column6: what I would call
column7: mirror game of ""here-it-is-and-here-it-isn't."" Uh - On the one hand
column8: for example
column9: he suggests that as far as his medical care program is concerned that that really isn't a problem because it's from Social Security. But Social Security is a tax. The people pay it. It comes right out of your paycheck. This doesn't mean that the people aren't going to be paying the bill. He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours. Well
column10: all that I can suggest is that all the experts who have studied the program indicate that it is the most fantastic program
column11: the worst program
column12: insofar as its effect on the farmers
column13: that the - America has ever had foisted upon it in an election year or any other time. And I would also point out that Senator Kennedy left out a part of the cost of that program - a twenty-five percent rise in food prices that the people would have to pay. Now are we going to have that when it isn't going to help the farmers? I don't think we should have that kind of a program. Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way. Well
column14: what he is saying there in effect
column15: we're going to have inflation. We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board. I don't believe we ought to pay our bills through inflation
column16: through a phony interest rate.

column9: will cost a billion dollars more than the present program
column10: which costs about six billion dollars a year
column11: the most expensive in history. We've spent more money on agriculture in the last eight years than the hundred years of the Agricultural Department before that. Secondly
column12: I believe that the high interest-rate policy that this Administration has followed has added about three billion dollars a year to interest on the debt - merely funding the debt - which is a burden an the taxpayers. I would hope
column13: under a different monetary policy
column14: that it would be possible to reduce that interest-rate burden
column15: at least a billion dollars. Third
column16: I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding
column18: I have suggested that the medical care for the aged - and the bill which the Congress now has passed and the President signed if fully implemented would cost a billion dollars on the Treasury - out of Treasury funds and a billion dollars by the states - the proposal that I have put forward and which many of the members of my party support is for medical care financed under Social Security; which would be financed under the Social Security taxes; which is less than three cents a day per person for medical care
column19: doctors' bills
column22: when they retire. It is actuarially sound. So in my judgment we would spend more money in this Administration on aid to education
column23: we'd spend more money on housing
column24: we'd spend more money and I hope more wisely on defense than this Administration has. But I believe that the next Administration should work for a balanced budget
column25: and that would be my intention. Mr. Nixon misstates my figures constantly
column26: which uh - is of course his right
column27: but the fact of the matter is: here is where I stand and I just want to have it on the public record.

column1: Senator Kennedy has indicated on several occasions in this program tonight that I have been misstating his record and his figures. I will issue a white paper after this broadcast
column2: quoting exactly what he said on compulsory arbitration
column4: and the record will show that I have been correct. Now as far as his figures are concerned here tonight
column5: he again is engaging in this
column6: what I would call
column7: mirror game of ""here-it-is-and-here-it-isn't."" Uh - On the one hand
column8: for example
column9: he suggests that as far as his medical care program is concerned that that really isn't a problem because it's from Social Security. But Social Security is a tax. The people pay it. It comes right out of your paycheck. This doesn't mean that the people aren't going to be paying the bill. He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours. Well
column10: all that I can suggest is that all the experts who have studied the program indicate that it is the most fantastic program
column11: the worst program
column12: insofar as its effect on the farmers
column13: that the - America has ever had foisted upon it in an election year or any other time. And I would also point out that Senator Kennedy left out a part of the cost of that program - a twenty-five percent rise in food prices that the people would have to pay. Now are we going to have that when it isn't going to help the farmers? I don't think we should have that kind of a program. Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way. Well
column14: what he is saying there in effect
column15: we're going to have inflation. We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board. I don't believe we ought to pay our bills through inflation
column16: through a phony interest rate.

column4: and the record will show that I have been correct. Now as far as his figures are concerned here tonight
column5: he again is engaging in this
column6: what I would call
column7: mirror game of ""here-it-is-and-here-it-isn't."" Uh - On the one hand
column8: for example
column9: he suggests that as far as his medical care program is concerned that that really isn't a problem because it's from Social Security. But Social Security is a tax. The people pay it. It comes right out of your paycheck. This doesn't mean that the people aren't going to be paying the bill. He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours. Well
column10: all that I can suggest is that all the experts who have studied the program indicate that it is the most fantastic program
column11: the worst program
column12: insofar as its effect on the farmers
column13: that the - America has ever had foisted upon it in an election year or any other time. And I would also point out that Senator Kennedy left out a part of the cost of that program - a twenty-five percent rise in food prices that the people would have to pay. Now are we going to have that when it isn't going to help the farmers? I don't think we should have that kind of a program. Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way. Well
column14: what he is saying there in effect
column15: we're going to have inflation. We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board. I don't believe we ought to pay our bills through inflation
column16: through a phony interest rate.

column4: I have stated in both uh - debates and state again that I believe in a balanced budget and have supported that concept during my fourteen years in the Congress. The only two times when an unbalanced budget is warranted would be during a serious recession - and we had that in fifty-eight in an unbalanced budget of twelve billion dollars - or a national emergency where there should be large expenditures for national defense
column5: which we had in World War II and uh - during part of the Korean War. On the question of the cost of our budget
column6: I have stated that it's my best judgment that our agricultural program will cost a billion and a half
column7: possibly two billion dollars less than the present agricultural program. My judgment is that the program the Vice President put forward
column8: which is an extension of Mr. Benson's program
column9: will cost a billion dollars more than the present program
column10: which costs about six billion dollars a year
column11: the most expensive in history. We've spent more money on agriculture in the last eight years than the hundred years of the Agricultural Department before that. Secondly
column12: I believe that the high interest-rate policy that this Administration has followed has added about three billion dollars a year to interest on the debt - merely funding the debt - which is a burden an the taxpayers. I would hope
column13: under a different monetary policy
column14: that it would be possible to reduce that interest-rate burden
column15: at least a billion dollars. Third
column16: I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding
column18: I have suggested that the medical care for the aged - and the bill which the Congress now has passed and the President signed if fully implemented would cost a billion dollars on the Treasury - out of Treasury funds and a billion dollars by the states - the proposal that I have put forward and which many of the members of my party support is for medical care financed under Social Security; which would be financed under the Social Security taxes; which is less than three cents a day per person for medical care
column19: doctors' bills
column22: when they retire. It is actuarially sound. So in my judgment we would spend more money in this Administration on aid to education
column23: we'd spend more money on housing
column24: we'd spend more money and I hope more wisely on defense than this Administration has. But I believe that the next Administration should work for a balanced budget
column25: and that would be my intention. Mr. Nixon misstates my figures constantly
column26: which uh - is of course his right
column27: but the fact of the matter is: here is where I stand and I just want to have it on the public record.

He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours. Well

Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way. Well

column15: we're going to have inflation. We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board. I don't believe we ought to pay our bills through inflation

column4: I have stated in both uh - debates and state again that I believe in a balanced budget and have supported that concept during my fourteen years in the Congress. The only two times when an unbalanced budget is warranted would be during a serious recession - and we had that in fifty-eight in an unbalanced budget of twelve billion dollars - or a national emergency where there should be large expenditures for national defense
column5: which we had in World War II and uh - during part of the Korean War. On the question of the cost of our budget
column6: I have stated that it's my best judgment that our agricultural program will cost a billion and a half
column7: possibly two billion dollars less than the present agricultural program. My judgment is that the program the Vice President put forward
column8: which is an extension of Mr. Benson's program
column9: will cost a billion dollars more than the present program
column10: which costs about six billion dollars a year
column11: the most expensive in history. We've spent more money on agriculture in the last eight years than the hundred years of the Agricultural Department before that. Secondly
column12: I believe that the high interest-rate policy that this Administration has followed has added about three billion dollars a year to interest on the debt - merely funding the debt - which is a burden an the taxpayers. I would hope
column13: under a different monetary policy
column14: that it would be possible to reduce that interest-rate burden
column15: at least a billion dollars. Third
column16: I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding
column18: I have suggested that the medical care for the aged - and the bill which the Congress now has passed and the President signed if fully implemented would cost a billion dollars on the Treasury - out of Treasury funds and a billion dollars by the states - the proposal that I have put forward and which many of the members of my party support is for medical care financed under Social Security; which would be financed under the Social Security taxes; which is less than three cents a day per person for medical care
column19: doctors' bills
column22: when they retire. It is actuarially sound. So in my judgment we would spend more money in this Administration on aid to education
column23: we'd spend more money on housing
column24: we'd spend more money and I hope more wisely on defense than this Administration has. But I believe that the next Administration should work for a balanced budget
column25: and that would be my intention. Mr. Nixon misstates my figures constantly
column26: which uh - is of course his right
column27: but the fact of the matter is: here is where I stand and I just want to have it on the public record.

column1: Senator Kennedy has indicated on several occasions in this program tonight that I have been misstating his record and his figures. I will issue a white paper after this broadcast
column2: quoting exactly what he said on compulsory arbitration
column4: and the record will show that I have been correct. Now as far as his figures are concerned here tonight
column5: he again is engaging in this
column6: what I would call
column7: mirror game of ""here-it-is-and-here-it-isn't."" Uh - On the one hand
column8: for example
column9: he suggests that as far as his medical care program is concerned that that really isn't a problem because it's from Social Security. But Social Security is a tax. The people pay it. It comes right out of your paycheck. This doesn't mean that the people aren't going to be paying the bill. He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours. Well
column10: all that I can suggest is that all the experts who have studied the program indicate that it is the most fantastic program
column11: the worst program
column12: insofar as its effect on the farmers
column13: that the - America has ever had foisted upon it in an election year or any other time. And I would also point out that Senator Kennedy left out a part of the cost of that program - a twenty-five percent rise in food prices that the people would have to pay. Now are we going to have that when it isn't going to help the farmers? I don't think we should have that kind of a program. Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way. Well
column14: what he is saying there in effect
column15: we're going to have inflation. We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board. I don't believe we ought to pay our bills through inflation
column16: through a phony interest rate.
